instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
dont know history(but no water damage), someone play with the board before.
when it arrive to me <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> was short, i was fix it.
now, on one usb port it show 5v 0.3a and nothing on the other, i was replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and fix some caps there and now both usb show 5v 0.3a and every 10sec its of and on again.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_3GH</SIGNAL> 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
with battery connected:
usb port #1 is show 5v 0.3a then off and not turning on again on again(the [I]USB Voltmeter[/I] ) 
usb port  #2 5v 0a

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings between both ports.
I suspect knocked off components, intentionally maybe.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
all LDO look fine in diode mode and voltage.
<DIODE>D3387</DIODE> was off i was replace  it.
also <DIODE>D3320</DIODE> was bad and i was replace it.
still act the same..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
both 5v 0.25-0.3A whiteout battery.
with battery: its start 5V 0.3A and then sown to 0A and when i take the charger out and plug again its dead, until I'm unplug the battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message: What was the shorted component on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
"it arrive to me <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> was short"
<CAPACITOR>C7690</CAPACITOR> isn't on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
i was put 1v with high AMP and after a 1sec the short was disappear and i was get 3.3v on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>,
i didnt see and bad cap on  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> rail and <CAPACITOR>C7690</CAPACITOR> was missing so i thought maybe he was blow out.
weird but all  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> rail look o.k.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
The "hidden" culprit on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> is probably the real problem.
This repair is probably waste of time, after board was messed off in other place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message: But <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> rail not so big, what I need to search for?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message: Look if something looks cracked/burnt there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
Donâ€™t find one, but if I get 3.3v on this rail, so the rail is fine no?
Do <CAPACITOR>C7690</CAPACITOR> is important?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7690</CAPACITOR> is not so critical as Apple wants you to believe.

You have now correct <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>, but there is a bad component; which doesn't make its job.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 90321, member: 682"]
which doesn't make its job.
[/QUOTE]
And it can be the reason for 20v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
Unfortunately, yes.
Critical components, like T2, PMIC and <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips are powered from this rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:
You may find that is correct value, comparing with working board.

Looks like wasting time, once you can't find what was bad component connected to <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>.
Short has gone, but think that internal connection is broken now; it is not powered in fact.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.3A
threads.message:

Notice that pp5v rails are missing, no short.
